ground_truth: The hobos stare as Everett gives an ingratiating smile while the second convict begins to haul himself into the boxcar and the third convict keeps pace outside. The convict running outside stumbles and disappears, and the middle convict is yanked out immediately after. Everett, just finishing his speech, flips forward, smashes his chin onto the floor, and is sucked out the open doorway, his fingernails leaving grooves on the boxcar floorboards. The hobos impassively watch as the three men tumble down the track embankment, clanking. They come to a rest in swampland at the bottom, then shake their heads clear, rise to their feet in the muck, and watch the train recede, leaving only the baying of hounds. Everett looks desperately about, and the two other men look interrogatively to Delmar, who looks from Pete to Everett and nods agreeably. Everett makes a sudden hushing gesture, and all listen. The men turn in unison to look up the track at a small, distant form moving toward them, which resolves into a human-propelled flatcar as it draws closer. An ancient black man rhythmically pumps its long seesaw handle. The three convicts watch the swampland, which begins to show movement as men and dogs trample the grass. The flatcar draws even and slows, and the three men clamber aboard as the old man resumes pumping. The three convicts, faces upturned, listen raptly to the blind prophet while the cloudy eyes of the old man stare sightlessly down the track with the seesaw handle rising and falling. The old man pumps rhythmically, and all contemplate his words. Suddenly, a rifle shot kicks up dust in front of the men. The front of the farmhouse shows a harshly shaded porch and a dark screen door, which swings open as a child holding a gun emerges and steps into the sunlight; the child is about eight years old with grimy face and tattered overalls. He pokes his rifle at the three men, who raise their hands. Wash Hogwallop, a sour-looking bald man, sits near a rusted bathtub amidst a yard of ancient car parts and farm implements overgrown with weeds, artlessly whittling a stick. He glances up as the three convicts clank around the corner, then returns to his whittling. The four men and the little boy sit around the kitchen table eating stew, with a Sears Roebuck catalogue on the boy's chair bringing him to table height. Wash glances at the little boy as the three men slurp their stew, while he sniffs dubiously at his spoon.

test_cases.name: Synonym Substitution
test_cases.description: The vagabonds gaze as Everett delivers an ingratiating grin while the second inmate starts to hoist himself into the boxcar and the third prisoner maintains pace outside. The convict sprinting outside trips and vanishes, and the middle prisoner is pulled out immediately afterward. Everett, just concluding his oration, flips forward, smashes his jaw onto the floor, and is sucked out the open portal, his fingernails leaving furrows on the boxcar planks. The vagrants impassively observe as the three individuals tumble down the track embankment, clattering. They arrive to a halt in wetland at the bottom, then shake their heads clear, rise to their legs in the mire, and watch the locomotive recede, leaving only the baying of hounds. Everett glances desperately around, and the two other individuals look questioningly to Delmar, who looks from Pete to Everett and nods agreeably. Everett makes a sudden hushing motion, and all listen. The individuals turn in unison to gaze up the track at a small, distant figure moving toward them, which resolves into a human-propelled handcar as it draws nearer. An ancient black man rhythmically pumps its long seesaw lever. The three prisoners watch the wetland, which begins to show motion as men and dogs trample the grass. The handcar draws even and slows, and the three individuals scramble aboard as the old man resumes pumping. The three convicts, faces upturned, listen attentively to the blind prophet while the cloudy eyes of the old man gaze sightlessly down the track with the seesaw lever rising and falling. The old man pumps rhythmically, and all ponder his words. Suddenly, a firearm shot kicks up dust in front of the individuals. The front of the farmhouse displays a harshly shaded porch and a dark screen door, which swings open as a youngster holding a rifle emerges and steps into the sunlight; the child is about eight years old with grimy visage and tattered overalls. He pokes his rifle at the three individuals, who raise their hands. Wash Hogwallop, a sour-looking bald man, sits near a corroded bathtub amidst a yard of ancient automobile parts and farm implements overgrown with weeds, artlessly carving a stick. He glances up as the three prisoners clatter around the corner, then returns to his carving. The four individuals and the little boy sit around the kitchen table consuming stew, with a Sears Roebuck catalogue on the boy's chair bringing him to table height. Wash glances at the little boy as the three individuals slurp their stew, while he sniffs dubiously at his utensil.

test_cases.name: Active <-> Passive Transformation
test_cases.description: The hobos are stared at as Everett is given an ingratiating smile while the second convict is beginning to haul himself into the boxcar, and the third convict is kept pace with outside. The convict running outside is stumbled and disappeared, and the middle convict yanks him out immediately after. Everett, just finishing his speech, is flipped forward, smashes his chin onto the floor, and is sucked out the open doorway, grooves being left on the boxcar floorboards by his fingernails. The three men are watched impassively by the hobos as they are tumbled down the track embankment, clanking. A rest is come to by them in swampland at the bottom, then their heads are shaken clear, they rise to their feet in the muck, and the train is watched receding, leaving only the baying of hounds. A desperate look is given about by Everett, and an interrogative look is given to Delmar by the two other men, who looks from Pete to Everett and nods agreeably. A sudden hushing gesture is made by Everett, and listening is done by all. The track is turned to in unison by the men, looking at a small, distant form moving toward them, which is resolved into a human-propelled flatcar as it is drawn closer. Its long seesaw handle is rhythmically pumped by an ancient black man. The swampland is watched by the three convicts, which begins to show movement as the grass is trampled by men and dogs. The flatcar is drawn even and slowed, and the three men clamber aboard as the old man resumes pumping. The blind prophet is listened to raptly by the three convicts, faces upturned, while the cloudy eyes of the old man sightlessly stare down the track with the seesaw handle rising and falling. His words are contemplated, rhythmically pumped by the old man. Suddenly, dust is kicked up by a rifle shot in front of the men. A harshly shaded porch and a dark screen door are shown by the front of the farmhouse, which is swung open as a child holding a gun emerges and steps into the sunlight; the child has a grimy face and tattered overalls and is about eight years old. His rifle is poked at the three men by him, who raise their hands. Wash Hogwallop, a sour-looking bald man, is sat near a rusted bathtub amidst a yard of ancient car parts and farm implements overgrown with weeds, a stick being artlessly whittled by him. He glances up as the corner is clanked around by the three convicts, then he returns to his whittling. The kitchen table is sat around by the four men and the little boy eating stew, with a Sears Roebuck catalogue being on the boy's chair bringing him to table height. The little boy is glanced at by Wash as he sniffs dubiously at his spoon while the three men slurp their stew.

test_cases.name: Brevity - L1
test_cases.description: The hobos watch as Everett smiles ingratiatingly, the second convict clambers into the boxcar, and the third matches pace outside. The outside convict stumbles and vanishes, pulling the middle one out immediately after. Everett finishes his speech, flips forward, hits his chin on the floor, and is drawn out, scratching the boxcar floorboards. The hobos observe impassively as the men tumble down the embankment into the swampland, rise in the muck, and watch the train leave to the baying of hounds. The men look to Delmar, who nods, while Everett listens intently. They see a distant form approaching, resolving into a human-powered flatcar with an old black man rhythmically pumping. The swamp stirs as men and dogs appear, and the flatcar slows for the convicts to board. They listen to the blind prophet as he pumps steadily, contemplating his words. Suddenly, a rifle shot hits the ground. A porch reveals a dark screen door; a boy about eight, with a dirty face and tattered overalls, emerges from the door, aiming his gun at the convicts. Wash Hogwallop, a bald man, whittles near a rusted bathtub among overgrown car parts, glancing at the convicts before continuing his work. All four men and the boy sit eating stew at the kitchen table, the boy's chair elevated with a Sears Roebuck catalogue. Wash sniffs dubiously at his spoon as the others slurp their stew.

test_cases.name: Brevity - L2
test_cases.description: Everett smiles at hobos as a convict climbs into the boxcar and another runs outside, stumbling and disappearing. The second convict is pulled out, and Everett flips forward, hitting his chin and getting sucked out, leaving nail grooves. Hobos watch the convicts tumble down an embankment into a swamp. They stand, watching the train leave with baying hounds. Everett looks around, and the men look to Delmar, who nods. Everett hushes them, and they see a distant flatcar, which becomes clearer as an old black man pumps it closer. They climb aboard, listening to the blind prophet's words while he pumps rhythmically. A rifle shot hits dust, revealing a grimy child with a gun, who confronts them, making them raise their hands. Wash Hogwallop sits whittling as the convicts arrive. All four men and the boy eat stew at a kitchen table, with a Sears Roebuck catalogue boosting the boy’s seat. Wash glances at the boy while the convicts slurp, and he sniffs his spoon dubiously.

test_cases.name: Verbosity - L1
test_cases.description: The hobos stand silently by, their eyes fixed on the scene unfolding before them, as Everett flashes an ingratiating smile. Meanwhile, the second convict struggles valiantly to haul himself into the moving boxcar, while the third convict valiantly works to keep pace alongside, running with determination outside. In an unfortunate turn of events, the convict sprinting outside stumbles unexpectedly and disappears from sight, and moments later, the middle convict is suddenly yanked out in quick succession. Simultaneously, Everett, just as he is winding up his speech, unexpectedly flips forward, his chin striking the floor with a painful smash, and he is unceremoniously sucked out through the open doorway, his fingernails leaving deep grooves on the boxcar's wooden floorboards in a desperate bid to hold on. The hobos watch dispassionately, their faces impassive, as the three men cascade down the track embankment with a loud clanking. Eventually, they come to a rest in the swampland at the bottom of the embankment. Dazed, they shake their heads vigorously to clear the fog, rising to their feet in the squelching muck. As they regain their composure, they look on and watch the receding train, which leaves behind only the distant baying of hounds as a fading echo. Everett casts his gaze about with a look of desperation, while the two other men turn their eyes inquisitively toward Delmar, who glances from Pete to Everett before nodding agreeably. Suddenly, Everett makes a sharp hushing gesture, and all three listen intently. Their attention shifts in unison up the track, locking onto a small, distant form that slowly resolves into a human-powered flatcar as it approaches. In rhythmic motion, an ancient black man is seen pumping the flatcar's long seesaw handle with practiced ease. The three convicts watch as the swampland begins to show signs of movement, with men and dogs pressing through the underbrush. As the flatcar draws nearer and slows, the three men scramble aboard, and the old man resumes his rhythmic pumping. The convicts, their faces turned upwards, are captivated, listening intently to the words of the blind prophet. The cloudy, sightless eyes of the old man remain fixed down the track, even as the seesaw handle rises and falls with steady precision. The rhythmic pumping continues as they reflect deeply on his words. Suddenly, a sharp rifle shot ruptures the air, kicking up a cloud of dust in front of them. The farmhouse comes into view, its front shaded harshly, revealing a dark screen door that swings open with a creak. A child, no more than eight years old, emerges into the sunlight, his face grimy and overalls tattered. Clutching a gun, he steps forward, pokes the rifle pointedly at the trio, prompting them to raise their hands in surrender. Nearby, Wash Hogwallop, a sour-faced bald man, reclines casually near a rusted bathtub amidst a yard cluttered with ancient car parts and farm implements, long neglected and overgrown with weeds, meticulously whittling a stick with careless ease. He glances up briefly as the three convicts clatter noisily around the corner, then returns to his whittling with disinterest. Later, the four men and the little boy gather around the kitchen table, sharing a hearty meal of stew. The boy, seated with the help of a Sears Roebuck catalogue on his chair to bring him to table height, eats with them. Wash occasionally glances at the boy as the three convicts slurp noisily at their stew, while he sniffs at his spoon with a dubious expression.

test_cases.name: Verbosity - L2
test_cases.description: The hobos stand silently by, their eyes unwaveringly fixed on the dramatic scene that is unfolding right before them, as Everett, with an ingratiating grin spread wide across his face, attempts to charm his way through the situation. Meanwhile, the second convict is engaged in a valiant struggle, exerting all his energy to hoist himself up and into the fast-moving boxcar, while the third convict makes a determined effort to maintain his pace outside, running with unyielding resolve alongside the train. However, in a rather unfortunate twist of fate, the convict who is sprinting vigorously outside suddenly loses his footing and stumbles unexpectedly, vanishing instantaneously from view. Moments later, in rapid succession, the convict in the middle is abruptly pulled out, leaving behind only a fleeting moment of surprise. At the same instant, Everett, just as he nears the conclusion of his speech, unexpectedly flips forward, his chin crashing painfully onto the hard floor with a resounding thud, and he is unceremoniously sucked out through the open doorway. His fingernails leave deep grooves on the boxcar's wooden floorboards in a desperate, yet futile, attempt to hold on. As these chaotic events unfold, the hobos continue to watch with a dispassionate gaze, their faces remaining impassive and unmoved, as the three men cascade noisily down the track embankment with an unmistakable clanking sound. Eventually, they come to a rest, finding themselves in the swampland at the bottom of the embankment. Dazed and disoriented, they vigorously shake their heads in an attempt to clear the fog clouding their minds, rising unsteadily to their feet in the squelching muck underfoot. As they gradually regain their composure, they look on toward the horizon and watch the receding train, which leaves behind only the distant, fading echo of baying hounds. Everett casts his gaze about with an air of desperation, while the two other men turn their eyes inquisitively toward Delmar, who, after a glance from Pete to Everett, nods in agreeable understanding. Suddenly, Everett makes a sharp hushing gesture, and all three men freeze, listening with intense concentration. Their attention shifts collectively up the track, locking onto a small and distant form that slowly resolves into a human-powered flatcar as it approaches steadily. In a steady, rhythmic motion, an ancient black man is seen pumping the flatcar's long seesaw handle with a practiced ease that speaks of experience. The three convicts watch, their curiosity piqued, as the swampland begins to show signs of life, with men and dogs pressing through the dense underbrush. As the flatcar draws nearer and slows to a stop, the three men, seizing the opportunity, scramble aboard, and the old man resumes his rhythmic pumping. The convicts, with their faces turned upwards in a mixture of wonder and trepidation, listen intently to the words of the blind prophet. The cloudy, sightless eyes of the old man remain fixed unwaveringly down the track, even as the seesaw handle rises and falls with steady precision, maintaining its rhythmic cadence. The steady pumping continues, and the three men reflect deeply on his cryptic words. Suddenly, the calm is shattered by a sharp rifle shot that ruptures the air, sending a cloud of dust into the air just in front of them. A farmhouse gradually comes into view, its front shaded harshly, revealing a dark screen door that swings open with a disconcerting creak. From the doorway emerges a child, no more than eight years of age, stepping into the bright sunlight. His face is streaked with grime, and his overalls are notably tattered. Clutching a gun with determination, he steps forward boldly and pointedly pokes the rifle at the trio, prompting them to instinctively raise their hands in a gesture of surrender. Nearby, Wash Hogwallop, a sour-faced, bald man, reclines casually near a rusted bathtub amidst a yard cluttered with ancient car parts and neglected farm implements, long overgrown with weeds. He is meticulously whittling a stick with a careless ease that suggests disinterest. He glances up briefly as the three convicts clatter noisily around the corner, and then, with a disinterested air, returns to his whittling. Later, at a time when the day has given way to evening, the four men and the young boy gather around the kitchen table, sharing a hearty meal of stew. The boy, seated with the assistance of a thick Sears Roebuck catalogue placed on his chair to bring him to table height, eats alongside them. Wash occasionally glances at the boy with a mixture of affection and curiosity as the three convicts slurp noisily at their stew, while he sniffs at his spoon with a dubious expression, pondering the quality of the food.

test_cases.name: Macro-Actions -> Micro-Actions
test_cases.description: The hobos fixate intensely as Everett, aiming to be affable, beams a particularly ingratiating smile toward them. Meanwhile, the second convict makes a determined effort, hoisting himself into the boxcar with some struggle, and the third convict maintains a steady pace just outside the moving train. As the train progresses, the convict running alongside stumbles dramatically and vanishes from view, causing sudden panic. In the immediate aftermath, the middle convict is abruptly pulled out of the boxcar, his movement swift and unanticipated. Everett, just as he concludes his speech with a flourish, is caught off guard; he pitches forward unexpectedly, his chin making harsh contact with the boxcar floor. In the next moment, the force of the moving train pulls him relentlessly toward the open doorway. As he is ejected, his fingernails desperately drag along the wooden floor, creating visible grooves. The hobos, unmoved by the chaos, look on as the three men tumble unceremoniously down the track's embankment with loud clinking noises resonating. The men eventually come to rest in a muddy swampland at the bottom of the incline, momentarily dazed. They shake their heads vigorously to regain clarity, then slowly rise to their feet, the muck clinging to their clothes. As they steady themselves, their eyes follow the train, now receding into the distance, leaving behind the haunting echo of baying hounds. Everett, filled with desperation, quickly surveys the surroundings, while the other two men look toward Delmar with questioning expressions. Delmar, caught between the expectant gazes of Pete and Everett, nods in a manner that conveys both understanding and agreement. Everett swiftly signals for silence with a sharp hushing gesture, prompting all the men to listen intently. Their attention is abruptly drawn to a small, distant figure that gradually appears to be moving toward them along the track. As it approaches, it becomes clear that the figure is a human-propelled flatcar. An elderly black man stands atop it, expertly pumping the long seesaw handle with rhythmic precision. The convicts watch the swampland come alive as men and dogs begin to trample through the tall grass. When the flatcar comes level with them and decelerates slightly, the three men eagerly scramble aboard. As they settle in, the old man resumes his pumping, and the convicts, faces turned upward with rapt attention, listen carefully to the blind prophet's words. The old man, his cloudy eyes fixed sightlessly on the horizon, continues his rhythmic motion, the seesaw handle rising and falling methodically, prompting contemplation from all present. Suddenly, a rifle shot interrupts the scene, sending dust flying up from the ground just before the men. Their attention is snatched to the front of a farmhouse where a porch casts harsh shadows and a dark screen door swings open revealing a child. The young boy, about eight years old with a dirty face and wearing tattered overalls, steps confidently into the sunlight, clutching a rifle with determination. He jabs the weapon toward the three men, who instinctively lift their hands in a gesture of surrender. Nearby, Wash Hogwallop, appearing sour and bald, is seated near an old bathtub amidst a yard cluttered with ancient car parts and overgrown farm implements. He is engaged in the simple task of whittling a stick. At the clatter made by the approaching convicts, he glances up momentarily, acknowledges their presence with indifference, and goes back to his whittling. Later, the four men sit around a kitchen table, sharing a meal of stew. To accommodate the young boy, who needs extra height, a Sears Roebuck catalogue is placed on his chair. As the adults consume their stew with audible slurps, Wash glances at the boy with a hint of concern while giving his own spoonful a dubious sniff, appraising its suitability.

test_cases.name: Micro-Actions -> Macro-Actions
test_cases.description: As Everett finishes his ingratiating speech, the hobos observe indifferently while the second convict climbs into the boxcar and the third runs alongside. Both outside convicts stumble and fall, with Everett being pulled out as well, leaving grooves on the boxcar floor. The three men tumble down the track embankment into a swampland, where they regain their composure, rise, and watch the receding train amid the sound of baying hounds. Everett and his companions exchange looks of inquiry with Delmar, who nods in agreement, and Everett gestures for silence. The men then notice an approaching small flatcar, manually driven by an elderly, blind black man. As they board, they listen intently to his prophetic words while he pumps the seesaw handle rhythmically. Suddenly, a rifle shot kicks up dust, and they see a child emerging from a farmhouse to confront them with a gun, prompting the men to raise their hands. Nearby, Wash Hogwallop, a sour-looking man, sits whittling among rusty car parts. He briefly glances at the convicts as they arrive, then resumes his task. Later, all four men and the child gather around the kitchen table, where they eat stew, the child seated higher with the help of a Sears Roebuck catalogue. Wash watches the boy as he sniffs at his spoon, while the others slurp their stew.

test_cases.name: Insert Attributes, Emotions and Scene
test_cases.description: The hobos, often seen as transient workers during the Great Depression who traveled secretly on freight trains to seek employment, stare as Everett gives an ingratiating smile while the second convict begins to haul himself into the boxcar, a common method of illegal travel during that era, and the third convict keeps pace outside. The convict running outside stumbles and disappears, vanishing just as many did when confronted with the perilous life on the rails, and the middle convict is yanked out immediately after. Everett, just finishing his speech, flips forward, smashes his chin onto the floor with a painful thud, and is sucked out the open doorway, his fingernails leaving grooves on the boxcar floorboards, a testament to the desperation in his escape attempt. The hobos impassively watch as the three men tumble down the track embankment, clanking with the metallic sounds of their shackles. They come to a rest in swampland at the bottom, a common landscape in the southern United States where the story appears to be set, then shake their heads clear, rise to their feet in the muck, and watch the train recede, leaving only the baying of hounds, which were often used in that period to track escaped convicts. Everett looks desperately about, knowing the danger of recapture, and the two other men look interrogatively to Delmar, who looks from Pete to Everett and nods agreeably, hinting at a shared understanding or plan. Everett makes a sudden hushing gesture, and all listen. The men turn in unison to look up the track at a small, distant form moving toward them, which resolves into a human-propelled flatcar as it draws closer, a relic of old railroad maintenance methods. An ancient black man rhythmically pumps its long seesaw handle, evoking images of the hardships endured by African Americans in the post-Civil War South. The three convicts watch the swampland, which begins to show movement as men and dogs trample the grass, a hunt underway. The flatcar draws even and slows, and the three men clamber aboard as the old man resumes pumping. The three convicts, faces upturned, listen raptly to the blind prophet, often a symbolic figure in storytelling who represents insight beyond physical sight, while the cloudy eyes of the old man stare sightlessly down the track with the seesaw handle rising and falling. The old man pumps rhythmically, and all contemplate his words as if they hold some truth to their fate. Suddenly, a rifle shot kicks up dust in front of the men, a warning or perhaps a territorial assertion. The front of the farmhouse shows a harshly shaded porch and a dark screen door, which swings open as a child holding a gun emerges and steps into the sunlight; the child is about eight years old with a grimy face and tattered overalls, a typical look for children growing up in rural poverty during that era. He pokes his rifle at the three men, who raise their hands in surrender. Wash Hogwallop, a sour-looking bald man, sits near a rusted bathtub amidst a yard of ancient car parts and farm implements overgrown with weeds, artlessly whittling a stick, a pastime reflecting the slower pace and self-reliance of rural life. He glances up as the three convicts clank around the corner, then returns to his whittling. The four men and the little boy sit around the kitchen table eating stew, a humble meal often made from whatever ingredients were at hand, with a Sears Roebuck catalogue on the boy's chair bringing him to table height, illustrating how such catalogues were staples in American households, serving multiple purposes beyond just shopping. Wash glances at the little boy as the three men slurp their stew, while he sniffs dubiously at his spoon, perhaps questioning the quality of the meal or the circumstances of his unusual guests.

Amidst the roaring tempest of a stormy ocean a weathered sailor battles nature’s fury on a creaking vessel his resolve as steadfast as the crashing waves that threaten to engulf him. On a bustling 1960s New York street a passionate artist finds unexpected inspiration in the chaotic interplay of urban life capturing moments of love loss and defiant hope on a rainsoaked canvas. Deep in the heart of an enchanted forest a brave knight embarks on a perilous quest to rescue a captive princess facing mythical creatures and treacherous traps with unwavering courage. During a heated political rally in a futuristic city a charismatic leader stokes both hope and dissent. as holographic banners illuminate the night sky and fervent crowds surge with anticipation. In the eerie silence of a postapocalyptic wasteland a hardened survivor scavenges through abandoned ruins haunted by the echoes of a oncethriving civilization now reduced to dust. Beneath the shimmering surface of an underwater kingdom a rebellious mermaid defies ancient traditions to explore forbidden coral reefs and secret caverns brimming with forgotten lore. In the quiet confines of a suburban attic an unassuming teenager stumbles upon a mysterious portal that thrusts him into a surreal world where the very fabric of time and space unravels. On the rugged highlands of Scotland a stoic warrior faces rival clans and ancient curses alike his fierce battle cry resonating across mistcovered moors and turbulent skies. Amid the vibrant chaos of a South American carnival a fearless dancer twirls through streets bursting with color and rhythm each graceful move challenging the rigid boundaries of tradition. During a clandestine meeting in a snowcovered mountain lodge two rival spies exchange cryptic messages hinting at an imminent global conspiracy. The three convicts faces upturned listen raptly to the blind prophet while the cloudy eyes of the old man stare sightlessly down the track with the seesaw handle rising and falling. The old man pumps rhythmically and all contemplate his words. Suddenly a rifle shot kicks up dust in front of the men. The front of the farmhouse shows a harshly shaded porch and a dark screen door which swings open as a child holding a gun emerges and steps into the sunlight. the child is about eight years old with grimy face and tattered overalls. He pokes his rifle at the three men who raise their hands. Wash Hogwallop. a sourlooking bald man sits near a rusted bathtub amidst a yard of ancient car parts and farm implements overgrown with weeds artlessly whittling a stick. He glances up as the three convicts clank around the corner then returns to his whittling. The four men and the little boy sit around the kitchen table eating stew with a Sears Roebuck catalogue on the boy's chair bringing him to table height. Wash glances at the little boy as the three men slurp their stew while he sniffs dubiously at his spoon.

test_cases.name: Deletion (~50%)
test_cases.description: The hobos stare as Everett gives an ingratiating smile while the second convict begins to haul himself into the boxcar and the third convict keeps pace outside. The convict running outside stumbles and disappears and the middle convict is yanked out immediately after Everett just finishing his speech flips forward smashes his chin onto the floor and is sucked out the open doorway his fingernails leaving grooves on the boxcar floorboards. The hobos impassively watch as the three men tumble down the track embankment clanking. They come to a rest in swampland at the bottom then shake their heads clear rise to their feet in the muck and watch the train recede leaving only the baying of hounds. Everett looks desperately about and the two other men look interrogatively to Delmar who looks from Pete to Everett and nods agreeably. He pokes his rifle at the three men who raise their hands. Wash Hogwallop. a sourlooking bald man sits near a rusted bathtub amidst a yard of ancient car parts and farm implements overgrown with weeds artlessly whittling a stick. He glances up as the three convicts clank around the corner then returns to his whittling. The four men and the little boy sit around the kitchen table eating stew with a Sears Roebuck catalogue on the boy's chair bringing him to table height. Wash glances at the little boy as the three men slurp their stew while he sniffs dubiously at his spoon.

test_cases.name: Subject-Action-Object Corruption
test_cases.description: The squirrels gaze as Jasper offers a charming wave while the second traveler starts to drag himself onto the merry-go-round and the third traveler meanders nearby. The traveler jogging outside trips and vanishes, and the middle traveler is yanked off immediately afterward. Jasper, just concluding his monologue, somersaults forward, bashes his knee onto the ceiling, and is pulled out the open hatch, his shoelaces leaving lines on the merry-go-round panels. The squirrels passively observe as the three adventurers roll down the hill slope, clattering. They settle to a stop in the meadow at the base, then clear their hair, rise to their knees in the puddle, and observe the carousel retreating, leaving nothing but the chirping of crickets. Jasper glances frantically around, and the two other travelers glance questioningly to Harvey, who glances from Max to Jasper and grins approvingly. Jasper makes an abrupt whispering sign, and all listen. The travelers pivot simultaneously to peer up the hill at a tiny, distant silhouette approaching, which reveals a hand-propelled wagon as it nears. An ancient gray wolf steadily pushes its hefty lever. The three travelers observe the meadow, which starts to exhibit movement as cats and rabbits flatten the flowers. The wagon draws level and halts, and the three adventurers scramble aboard as the old wolf recommences pushing. The three travelers, faces uplifted, listen intently to the wise forecaster while the misty eyes of the old wolf gaze blindly past the hill with the hefty lever rising and descending. The old wolf pushes steadily, and all ponder his messages. Abruptly, an arrow strike kicks up stones in front of the travelers. The front of the barn displays a starkly shadowed porch and a dusky wooden gate, which creaks open as a kitten carrying a slingshot exits and steps into the moonlight; the kitten is about a year old with dusty fur and ragged boots. It aims its slingshot at the three adventurers, who lift their caps. Marty Bogwaddle, a grim-looking bearded elephant, lounges near a rusted watering can amidst a yard of forgotten bicycle parts and garden tools overgrown with moss, clumsily carving a log. He peers up as the three travelers clatter around the bush, then returns to his carving. The four adventurers and the tiny kitten lounge around the picnic blanket munching cookies, with a comic book under the kitten's paw bringing it to eye level. Marty glances at the tiny kitten as the three travelers gulp their cookies, while he sniffs skeptically at his mug.

test_cases.name: Complete Corruption
test_cases.description: The film starts with a man waking up in a small apartment. He prepares coffee and checks his phone for messages. There are none, so he heads out to catch a bus. On the way, he passes a neighbor who greets him briefly. At the bus stop, he notices a group of students talking about an upcoming test. He boards the bus and sits near the back, watching the city pass by outside the window. After a few stops, he gets off near a large office building. He enters the lobby and goes through security. He rides an elevator to the tenth floor, where he works as an assistant. His manager asks him to prepare some documents for a meeting later in the day. He collects files from different departments and organizes them in a conference room. Another employee asks him for help with a software issue, so he takes a few minutes to fix it. Then he returns to the conference room to double-check everything before the meeting begins. The meeting starts at noon. Several people join via video call, and others sit around the table. The manager outlines the project goals, and each team member shares updates on their tasks. There are questions about deadlines and budgets, but no big surprises. After an hour, they end the call. The manager thanks everyone and leaves. The assistant cleans up the room, collects leftover notes, and heads back to his desk. During lunch, he walks to a nearby café, where he orders a simple meal. He eats alone and checks social media on his phone. After lunch, he returns to the office and finishes smaller tasks, such as sending emails and filing paperwork. He also helps a coworker carry boxes of supplies to another floor. Later in the afternoon, the manager calls him in to discuss next week's schedule. They go over a few changes, and the assistant updates the calendar. When the workday ends, he logs off his computer and leaves the building. Outside, he walks a few blocks to meet a friend. They chat about weekend plans and decide to see a film on Saturday. The assistant then heads home on a crowded bus. At his apartment, he sorts his mail, feeds a pet cat, and warms up leftovers for dinner. He watches a short news segment on TV, then checks his phone again. A message from his friend confirms their plan for the weekend. He feels relieved to have something to look forward to. The film ends with him preparing for bed, setting an alarm, and turning off the lights. He reflects briefly on the day, thinking about his tasks, his quiet home, and the plans ahead.

test_cases.name: Summarization
test_cases.description: Everett smiles ingratiatingly, while one convict climbs into a boxcar and another keeps pace outside. The outside convict stumbles and disappears, quickly followed by the second. Everett, ending his speech, crashes forward and is pulled out, leaving marks on the floorboards. The hobos watch impassively as the men tumble down the embankment into a swamp. They rise, shaken, and watch the train leave as hounds bay. Everett looks around frantically, while Delmar nods agreeably to Pete and Everett. Everett gestures for silence; they spot a distant flatcar with an old black man pumping its handle. As it nears, the convicts board. They listen intently to the blind prophet as he pumps, ignoring the approaching men and dogs. A rifle shot startles them as a grimy boy with a gun emerges from a farmhouse. The convicts raise their hands. Wash Hogwallop, a bald man, glances up from whittling as they approach, then resumes. The group eats stew around the kitchen table, the boy sitting on a Sears Roebuck catalog. Wash eyes the boy, while the convicts slurp their stew.
